The *Luminous Percepts of the True* states: In the boundless world, men and women who live in the world and establish their conduct indulge in wine and lust, losing their nature in distraction, growing reckless and deluded. Their five emotions scatter in chaos, driving away spirit and harming qi. Drunk and greedy for desire, they commit evil unawares, shouting curses and vile words, acting alone without adversary. They strike the good, defile and scorn the Dao and its teachings, slander and destroy scriptures, turn from truth to falsehood, break promises and betray trust, deceive and malign the four assemblies. Their deeds stray from the Dao, and their sins run deep and perverse.

Upon death, they face heavy retribution: their souls endure bitter torment, drawing and pouring the dark waves to flood the Four Rivers. Banished to become rivers and streams, they toil day and night without rest, bound in iron fetters and shackles, dragged and pulled endlessly through the long, dark night, never to be freed. After ten thousand kalpas, they shall be born among thieves—poor, base, and afflicted with loathsome diseases, despised by all, repaying old enmities. The bonds of their karmic causes tighten, their path to fortune grows ever more distant, and their roots of sin take deeper hold. They cannot be delivered, nor find any way out.

The Flying Celestial Divine Person says: The *Luminous Percepts of the Jade Casket of the Nine Dark Realms of the Long Night’s Repository* enumerate fourteen categories of karmic retribution. Past deeds accumulate, bearing the weight of perverse and evil adversities. Good binds to good, evil follows evil, each adding to the other in an unbroken cycle. Having lost the human path, they do not even realize it, sinking into the six kinds of beasts. Even if reborn among humans, they shall be utterly foolish, or born among barbarians, or afflicted with the six illnesses, dragged and pulled endlessly for ten thousand kalpas with no escape. Their lives in the world are brief, but their deaths are long and sealed. Once they lose the path of goodness, they forever stray from the realm of the worthy. In the long, dark night, when shall they find deliverance?

Men and women of future generations, take heed and rouse yourselves! Establish great merit to redeem yourselves. Receive the Ten Precepts, and you may avoid this calamity. Remember well these words, and never forget them.

Thereupon, seven thousand two hundred and forty divine youths, the Great Perfected Saints of the heavens, all proclaimed their assent.

The Flying Celestial Divine Person having expounded the fourteen categories of karmic retribution for evil deeds and the unbroken bonds of evil causes, the divine youths rejoiced, paid homage, and then the Flying Celestial Divine Person spoke in verse:

Those who in life harbor no good thoughts,
Cruelly abuse their teachers and treasures,
Shall in death suffer ten thousand agonies,
And for ten thousand kalpas lose the human path.

Those who cruelly flatter the loyal and good,
Slander and strike the worthy,
Shall in life dwell among barbarians,
And in death take the form of oxen and horses.

Those who are miserly and greedy, desiring only gain,
Never thinking to give to living beings,
Shall in death become hungry ghosts,
And later be born as beasts of burden.

Those who in wealth and power oppress the poor and lowly,
Seize and separate others from their kin,
Shall in body suffer the retribution of being torn apart,
And their souls, as ghosts, endure shaving and branding.

Those who curse the innocent,
And in lewd rites dance for evil spirits,
Shall be dragged through the Three Wretched Realms,
And for ten thousand kalpas be born in lowly bodies.

Those who plot treason and abuse their lords and fathers,
Defile and disgrace the Celestial Perfected,
Shall in death be boiled in cauldrons of scalding water,
Their suffering unending, with no return.

Those whose minds are not steadfast and resolute,
Who slight and scorn the Heavenly Treasures of scripture,
Shall after death walk the path of sword trees,
Where wind and blades never cease.

Those who harbor no compassion,
But cruelly harm living beings,
Shall in death bear iron cauldrons,
And for ten thousand kalpas wear mountains of fire.

Those who betray the Dao and turn to evil spirits,
Slander and turn their backs on the Perfected,
Shall in death have no clothes to wear,
And iron rods shall never leave their bodies.

Those who rob and steal others’ wealth,
Cutting and stabbing the people of heaven,
Shall in death suffer shaving and amputation,
And in life be maimed by punishment.

Those who, under cover of darkness, break into homes,
And act wantonly as they please,
Shall in death be forever confined in darkness,
Never to see the light of sun or moon.

Those who accumulate deeds without thought of kindness,
And roam hunting to capture living beings,
Shall have their enmity repaid with iron rods,
Driven and chased without a moment’s rest.

Those of fierce nature who stir up strife with their tongues,
Creating discord among kin and stranger alike,
Shall in death suffer the retribution of having their tongues torn out,
And later be born to bark at others forever.

Those who love wine and lose their original conduct,
Their five spirits all growing reckless,
Shall in death draw the waters of the dark waves,
And pour them to flood the Four Rivers.

Thus the Flying Celestial Divine Person chanted in verse the karmic retribution of good and evil, proclaiming it to the divine youths. At that time, the celestial beings all awakened, clearly seeing the roots of their lives. They reflected on the sources of their past sins, reformed their hearts, and roused themselves to cultivate and uphold the scriptures. Their old debts were dispersed, the Nine Dark Realms were purified, and all were reborn amid good causes.

The divine youths received the Dharma-sound with reverence, rejoiced as one, paid homage, and departed.

The *Upper Grade on Deliverance from Karmic Retribution of Sin and Fortune in the Jade Casket of the Nine Dark Realms*

The Most High Lord of the Dao stepped forward, bowed, and addressed the Heavenly Worthy: Today, while attending in your presence, I have witnessed the divine youths receiving your majestic radiance, which illumines the halls of fortune in all the heavens and the hells of the boundless world, where the retribution of good and evil differs in suffering and joy. The good rejoice in peace, carefree and endless, while the evil wallow in misery, dragged through the Eight Difficulties, their bodies lost forever—how pitiable! Such retribution, bound to evil causes, faces endless kalpas of adversity, never recognizing the roots of their lives. Do they not possess merit to redeem and deliver the dead, to lead them out of the long night of the Nine Dark Realms, to enter the light, and be reborn in the gates of fortune?

If you would show compassion, the living and the dead would bear your grace. The departed would rest in peace, and the living would prosper, flourishing in wealth and honor, their lives long and enduring. Their influence would shade the eight distant lands, and their virtue would sprinkle the forests of orchids. Men and women of future generations would hear the Dharma-sound. I only pray, Heavenly Worthy, that you distinguish and explain, bestowing upon us the decisive words, so that all may see the precepts clearly and find peace.

The Heavenly Worthy addressed the Most High Lord of the Dao, saying: Listen well to my words, reflect deeply, and inscribe them in your heart. Day and night, hold them in mind, and never forget. I shall now explain the wondrous sound for you to follow, so that you may redeem sinful souls, open the way out of the long night, the Nine Dark Realms, and the Eight Difficulties. Their old adversities shall be dispersed, and they shall turn to the roots of faith, rejoicing in life and death, their karmic bonds spanning generations.

The method is most exalted and wondrous, transmitted but once in ten thousand kalpas. Only when a worthy and enlightened one appears in the world is it solemnly imparted. Kept secret, blessings descend; revealed, calamities draw near. The warning of the Wind and Blade is declared to the Perfected Illuminati—transgress the precepts and statutes, and blame not the heavens.

Thereupon, the Heavenly Worthy commanded the Flying Celestial Beings to expound the karmic retribution of sins and blessings, delivering the highest grade of souls. As the scripture was recited, the luminaries of the heavens—sun, moon, and stars—radiated their brilliance, universally illuminating the boundless worlds of the Nine Earths and the long-night abodes of the Nine Dark Realms. The long-bound hungry ghosts, the toiling dead souls, received the light upon their bodies and beheld their life-roots. Thereupon, they awakened, turning their hearts as one, all inclining toward goodness, contemplating the return to the gate of blessings. The Five Sufferings were dissolved, the Three Paths uplifted; karmic adversities were dispersed, and the hells found tranquility.

At that time, men and women universally heard the Dharma-sound. Those who had prepared their minds all attained divine transcendence.

The Flying Celestial Being declared: The *Highest Grade of the Jade Casket for Delivering the Dead from the Nine Dark Realms and Their Karmic Adversities* is to be performed during the six months of the year—namely, the first, third, fifth, seventh, ninth, and eleventh months. Within each month, on the first, eighth, fourteenth, fifteenth, eighteenth, twenty-third, twenty-fourth, twenty-eighth, twenty-ninth, and thirtieth days—a total of ten days—as well as on the Eight Seasonal Festivals, the days of *jiazi* and *gengshen*, one should set a tall lamp, nine feet high, in the central courtyard of the home. Upon this single lamp, kindle nine lamps, each radiating light to illuminate above the Nine Mysteries and the celestial halls of blessings, and below the boundless worlds of the Nine Earths and the long-night abodes.

In accordance with the ritual decorum and prescribed method, invoke and welcome the Heavenly Immortals, Earthly Immortals, Perfected Ones, Flying Immortals, the luminaries of the sun, moon, and stars, the Nine Palaces and Five Emperors, the Five Sacred Peaks and Three Rivers, the armies of the Four Seas—each numbering ninety-nine billion cavalry—as well as the thirty-two celestial overseers of the fast, the attendant incense-bearing Golden Lads, the flower-scattering Jade Maidens, the thirty-two direct messengers of the Five Emperors, and the flying dragon couriers who transmit words and memorials. Let them all descend together to oversee the ritual hall, receive the incense offerings, and bear the vows upward. When the circumambulation and rites are complete, they shall return to their celestial palaces.

By day, burn incense; by night, kindle lamps, ensuring the fragrance never ceases. Display the scripture in the courtyard beneath the nine lamps, circumambulate the lamps, and after offering incense and reciting vows, turn to the east and bow nine times, saying:

*"I, [Name], now take refuge in the Eastern Infinite Supreme Numinous Treasure Heavenly Worthy, the Great Sage Hosts who have attained the Dao, the Perfected Lords and Venerable Masters, the Nine Qi Heavenly Lords, and the myriad divine officials of the Eastern Realm. Today, I establish this fast, burn incense, and kindle lamps, dedicating these merits to illuminate all heavens. May they universally benefit the Emperor, lords of states, officials, common folk, Dharma-receiving masters, parents and honored kin, fellow disciples, recluses in the mountains and forests cultivating the true Dao, all worthy ones, the crawling and flying, wriggling and creeping, all sentient beings—may they all be delivered from the Ten Sufferings and Eight Difficulties, dwell eternally in non-action, and attain universal deliverance by nature. May the myriad generations of my ancestors, the imprisoned and wandering souls of my lineage, be bathed in light, liberated, and turned toward the roots of faith. If one merely adorns the exterior while the heart grows negligent, such prostrations weary the body in vain. Yet for those of sincere devotion, whose hearts and words align, the offering of incense and the voicing of vows already penetrate the myriad heavens—birth and death, sins and retributions, all dissolve without exception.

This merit is most weighty, praised throughout the Three Realms; its blessings towering and vast, beyond all measure. The Most High Dao Lord bowed deeply and addressed the Heavenly Worthy: "Now having heard the Flying Heavenly Spirits expound upon the karmic bonds of sin and blessing, the supreme methods of deliverance, the rites of supplication and gratitude, and the dissolution of deep-rooted transgressions—so that in future lives, men and women may receive this grace, attain universal deliverance, and enter the light—if such goodness is practiced, yet further methods remain, I ask: when heaven sends grave disasters, the nation’s destiny falters, the stars and constellations stray from their courses, the four seasons lose their order, warfare and pestilence arise, the emperor finds no peace, plagues spread, and heaven and humanity suffer harm—what methods should be employed to dispel these calamities, deliver from peril, and resolve all inauspicious omens? I humbly beseech your teaching, that we may practice and thereby harmonize heaven and earth, assist the nation, and establish merit."

"If your instructions are received and followed, then blessings will spread throughout the ten directions, the nation’s destiny will be secure, the emperor will flourish, the realm will rejoice in peace, and boundless fortune will endure, so that in future lives, all beings may hear the sound of the Dharma."

Thereupon, the Heavenly Worthy instructed the Flying Heavenly Spirits to expound fully upon the supreme methods of deliverance from karmic bonds of sin and blessing, and the salvation of the land from plagues, perils, and disasters—whatever had not yet been fully explained—so that the Most High Dao Lord might hear it all in detail. Thus, those who had not seen would see, those who had not heard would hear, and all beings would be universally taught, enabling them to behold the light. Having spoken thus, the Heavenly Worthy commanded that the essential instructions be reverently received.

The Flying Heavenly Spirits declared: "For the Nine Dark Realms of the Long Night’s Repository, the *Mingzhen Statutes* of the Jade Treasury prescribe this: when the emperor’s land suffers from pestilence, warfare, or dire peril, one must inscribe the five sacred texts of the *Lingbao True Writ* in cinnabar. In the central courtyard, arrange five altars corresponding to the five directions, placing one text upon each. Offer five taels of gold, fashioning one tael into a dragon for each, so that five dragons may guard the five texts. Further, present five-colored silken pledges to honor the Five Emperors. Those afflicted by calamity, according to their age, shall offer purple-silk writs to deliver their lives, secure the nation’s destiny, and dispel heavenly disasters, aligning the stars and constellations.

In spring, kindle nine lamps—or ninety, or nine hundred. In summer, kindle three lamps—or thirty, or three hundred. In autumn, kindle seven lamps—or seventy, or seven hundred. In winter, kindle five lamps—or fifty, or five hundred. During the intercalary months, kindle twelve lamps—or one hundred twenty, or one thousand two hundred. Additionally, set a tall lamp, nine feet in height, with nine lamps upon it, placed at the center to illuminate the Nine Dark Realms of the Long Night’s Repository.

The Great Dharma Master, standing at the center, shall loosen the hair and untie the topknot, anoint the body with mud and ashes, and perform the six-hour rites of supplication and gratitude while conducting the ritual in the central courtyard. If devout men and women wish to assist the nation in prayer, they shall scatter their hair and anoint themselves with mud and ashes at the gate, presenting their pleas.

In spring, the rites last nine days and nights; in summer, three days and nights; in autumn, seven days and nights; in winter, five days and nights; and during the intercalary months, twelve days and nights. Arraying the radiant lamps, their light will shine upon the boundless worlds within the Long Night, opening the Nine Dark Realms to clarity. The light will penetrate without end, the Three Luminaries will shine brightly, heaven and earth will be at peace, the stars and constellations will return to their places, the four seasons will harmonize, all calamities will vanish, warfare and pestilence will cease, heaven and humanity will rejoice, and the nation’s destiny will flourish.

When the day’s rites conclude, burn the true writs, dispersing them in the blue smoke."

The Flying Heavenly Spirits continued: "The Dharma Master shall enter through the Earth Gate, burn incense, and circumambulate the incense and lamps three times before standing facing east. Strike the teeth thirty-six times and invoke the furnace. Then invoke the furnace of the Supreme Three Heavens, the Primordial Qi of the Most High Dao Lord, summoning forth from within the master’s body the Three and Five Merit Officers, the Left and Right Attendants, the Left and Right Incense-Bearing Dragon Couriers, the Golden Lads of Incense, the Jade Maidens of Transmission, and the Five Emperors’ Direct Messengers—thirty-six of each—who shall emerge in solemn array. Notify the true officials of the four directions and the local deities: 'I now burn incense and perform the Dao rites. May the qi of the ten directions’ true perfected ones enter my body, so that my prayers swiftly ascend to the presence of the Most High, the Boundless Dao, the Supreme Worthy, the Jade Emperor.'

Thereafter, each shall declare their dharma rank: 'The humble disciple, the minor adept [Name], Great Dharma Master of the Three Caverns, respectfully addresses the Primordial Heavenly Worthy of the Void and the Natural, the Most High Dao Lord of the Boundless Dao, the Most High Lord Lao, the August Jade Emperor, the great sages who have attained the Dao, the perfected lords and venerable masters, the thirty-two Heavenly Emperors, the Jade Void Emperor, the Jade Emperor, the Great Emperor, the Eastern Flowery Peak, the Southern Culmen, the Western Numinous, the Northern Perfected, the Golden Towers and Jade Capitals of the Mystic Metropolis, the Seven Treasures and Mystic Terrace of the Purple Tenuity’s Upper Palace, and the Numinous Treasure Perfected Sovereign of the Radiant August Dao.

By the karmic conditions of my past lives, I was born into this Dharma gate. Through the mysterious and true deliverance, I entered the root of faith. My former master transmitted to me the sacred scriptures of the Three Treasures, and by the Dharma, I am to deliver ninety-nine thousand beings, ascending to the rank of the perfected. From my ancestors through the generations to my present life, I have encountered the scriptural teachings and dwelt always within blessings. Yet my merit is slight, my virtue meager, and I have not attained immortality. With exhausted devotion, I take refuge and vow to assist the nation and establish merit.

Now the land is in disharmony, warfare and pestilence arise together, yin and yang clash violently, the stars and constellations stray from their paths, and grave calamities press heavily. The circumstances are as described. Perhaps the emperor, having received the heavenly mandate to oversee the myriad people, has not yet fully extended his benevolence to nourish the ten directions, leaving heaven and humanity unprosperous and the nation unsettled. Without songs of praise, the roads echo with stifled sobs. Thus, the Three Luminaries grow dim and disordered, great disasters spread, the emperor is anxious, and the people find no peace.'"

The character *"et cetera"* is supplied according to the Dunhuang manuscripts. The character *"petition"* is likewise supplied. *"Emperors, kings, and lords of states"* appears as *"emperors, lords, and kings"* in the Dunhuang manuscripts, and this convention is maintained throughout without further annotation. *"Rulers, officials, and common folk"* appears as *"rulers, ministers, officials, and common folk"* in the Dunhuang manuscripts, and this is likewise followed in most subsequent instances without further annotation.

In the Dunhuang manuscripts, the petitionary invocations often replace *"so-and-so"* with *"Jia."* The term *"take refuge"* appears as *"return to refuge"* in the Dunhuang manuscripts. Hereafter, wherever *"take refuge,"* *"submit one’s life,"* or similar phrases appear, the Dunhuang manuscripts uniformly render them as *"return to refuge,"* *"return one’s life,"* or *"return one’s spirit,"* and no further annotations will be provided.

From *"Now, therefore, we establish this ritual fast..."* to *"unite with the Dao and merge with the True,"* the Dunhuang manuscripts abbreviate the entire petitionary invocation of over one hundred and fifty characters to *"May the above dharma be remembered with devotion."* This convention is maintained in subsequent passages without further annotation.

The three sections of scripture beginning with *"Next, bow once toward the southeast"* are condensed in the Dunhuang manuscripts as follows: *"Next, bow once toward the southeast, then the southwest, then the northwest—each of the four directions—with nine prostrations, nine bows touching the forehead to the ground, and nine invocations of submission, all performed in the same manner as for the northeast."*

*"Next, face the upper direction"* appears as *"After the four directions are completed, next face the northwest upper direction"* in the Dunhuang manuscripts. *"Next, face the lower direction"* appears as *"next face the southeast lower direction."*

*"Ninefold Walled Earthly Sovereigns"* appears as *"Ninefold Earthly Jade Sovereigns"* in the Dunhuang manuscripts. *"Military incursions"* was originally *"military epidemics"* and has been emended according to the Dunhuang manuscripts. *"Expounds"* appears as *"states the expounded"* in the Dunhuang manuscripts. *"Diseases and rashes"* appears as *"disasters and illnesses"* in the Dunhuang manuscripts, which is more accurate.

The Dunhuang manuscripts omit the phrase *"burn incense."* *"Activate the incense burner"* appears as *"declare, saying"* in the Dunhuang manuscripts. The Dunhuang manuscripts omit the phrase *"next, activate the incense burner."* *"The Attending Incense Golden Lads transmit the words of the Flower-Scattering Jade Maidens"* appears as *"the Attending Incense Jade Lads and Attending Incense Jade Maidens"* in the Dunhuang manuscripts.

The Dunhuang manuscripts omit the phrase *"next, each recites their dharma rank."* *"Your servant, so-and-so"* appears as *"Wang Jia"* in the Dunhuang manuscripts, and this convention is maintained throughout. The Dunhuang manuscripts omit the phrase *"Most High Lord Lao."*

*"Encounter"* appears as *"fall upon"* in the Dunhuang manuscripts. *"Perfected True"* appears as *"Highest True"* in the Dunhuang manuscripts. In the Dunhuang manuscripts, the character *"servant"* is followed by a small-character annotation: *"of the Dao’s lineage and virtue."* The character *"body"* is followed by the annotation *"later learners need only say"* in the Dunhuang manuscripts.

*"Submit one’s life"* appears as *"offer one’s body and life"* in the Dunhuang manuscripts. *"Disasters and illnesses"* appears as *"perils and disasters"* in the Dunhuang manuscripts. *"One fears that emperors may receive the heavenly mandate to abdicate"* appears as *"truly, as emperors receive the heavenly fortune"* in the Dunhuang manuscripts.

*"Incomplete"* appears as *"unable"* in the Dunhuang manuscripts. *"No songs are sung on the road, and voices are stifled"* appears as *"no grace is sung, and voices are stifled on the road"* in the Dunhuang manuscripts, with the subsequent *"thus"* rendered as *"thereby."*

Following the phrases *"Supervisors of the Ritual Fast, Attending Incense Golden Lads, and Flower-Scattering Jade Maidens,"* the Dunhuang manuscripts include *"thirty-two persons"* in each instance.

*"Those with meritorious service report their merits to the Three Officials"* appears as *"Those with diligent service petition the Transcendent Officials; then rise, face east, offer incense three times, and recite the incantation"* in the Dunhuang manuscripts, which omits the subsequent phrase *"next, take three pinches of incense."*

*"First pinch of incense"* appears as *"burn incense"* in the Dunhuang manuscripts. *"Now, therefore, your servant establishes this and takes a second pinch of incense"* appears as *"Next, take three more pinches of incense and recite the incantation: Now, therefore, your servant burns this incense"* in the Dunhuang manuscripts, and this convention is maintained for *"third pinch of incense."*

*"May your servant swiftly attain the Dao of immortality, along with nine generations of kin"* was originally *"May your servant attain the Dao of immortality and befriend nine kinds of relatives,"* and has been emended according to the Dunhuang manuscripts.

This sentence in the Dunhuang manuscripts reads: *"After the invocation for the offering of incense is completed, face east, bow nine times, and declare."* The Dunhuang manuscripts omit the phrase *"Most High Numinous Treasure."* In subsequent passages, the names of the Heavenly Worthies of the West, North, and other directions likewise omit *"Most High Numinous Treasure"* in the Dunhuang manuscripts.

*"Acknowledge faults and self-discipline"* was mistakenly written as *"seek and self-discipline,"* and has been emended according to the Dunhuang manuscripts. Hereafter, all instances of *"seek and self-discipline"* are emended accordingly without further annotation.
